posts.text: I keep finding Japanese architecture that most English-speaking audiences never see. Marble shoji screens, $110K thatched-roof houses in Kyoto, 100-year-old buildings turned into pop-up restaurants. Going to post what I find here.
posts.ig_skip_reason: too old to cross-post, marked during reconciliation

posts.text:
The point of a shoji screen is to divide a room without blocking light. NAP Architects sliced white marble down to 3 millimeters and set it into the existing frames. No structural changes to the building. The marble does what paper couldn't ‚Äî blocks sound, keeps the light. 3mm. Marble. ü§Ø
üì∑ @naparchitects

Thatched-roof kominka in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto. 4,191 square meters of land, hearth intact, original fittings, cherry trees in the garden. Listed at 16.8 million yen. That's about $110K for a house with its own forest.
üì∑ @530E
posts.ig_skip_reason: too old to cross-post, marked during reconciliation

posts.text:
100-year-old kominka, renovated into an inn. 10-tatami room with a kotatsu in the center. One heated table under a blanket. That's the heating system for the whole room. Showa-era, still running.
üì∑ @mm__ii89
posts.notes: Scheduled natively in X ‚Äî do not post via post.py

posts.text:
Kominka near Kudanshita Station, Tokyo. Slated for demolition in a redevelopment zone. Someone opened a one-year pop-up restaurant inside instead. ÈÖí„Å®„Å¶„Çâ„Å†„ÇÑ ‚Äî sake and small plates in a building that's running out of time.
üì∑ @WalkAroundTokyo
posts.notes: Rescheduled from Feb 13 back to Feb 10 afternoon gap.
posts.ig_skip_reason: too old to cross-post, marked during reconciliation

posts.text:
Kyoto International Conference Centre, 1966. Sachio Otani tilted every column 22 degrees off vertical. Hexagonal grid, almost no straight walls. The Kyoto Protocol was signed here. That's why it's called the Kyoto Protocol.

üì∑ @SciFiArchives
posts.notes: Modernist JP architecture. 16K likes on source. Moved to Feb 7 evening.

posts.text:
Shirakawa-go after snowfall. The thatched roofs are built at 60 degrees ‚Äî gassho-zukuri, 'hands in prayer.' The angle isn't decorative. It keeps 2 meters of annual snowfall from crushing the frame. Some of these houses are over 250 years old.
üì∑ @hitoritabiken
posts.notes: UNESCO site but winter snow angle is specific. 5.2K likes. Strong images.

posts.text:
Kumiko lattice panels. Small strips of wood interlocked by hand, no nails, no glue. Each geometric pattern has a name ‚Äî there are over 200. Most kumiko craftsmen train for 10+ years before they can cut the joints accurately enough.
üì∑ @Kanapi_House
posts.notes: Perfect niche content. Kumiko woodworking. Lower engagement on source but exactly our audience.

posts.text:
Rotenburo ‚Äî open-air hot spring bath. Stone, cedar, no enclosure. 42¬∞C water, snow falling on your shoulders. Most ryokan rotate bath access by gender every few hours. Some have private ones you can book.
üì∑ @tadanowanwan
posts.notes: Outdoor bath architecture. Sensory, specific. 604 likes.

posts.text:
Shimane. Wooden facades, tile roofs, covered walkways built for rain. Fewest visitors of any prefecture on Honshu. Home to Izumo Taisha. Most buildings here haven't been renovated in decades ‚Äî no tourist money.

üì∑ @cpgu_b24
posts.notes: Off-beaten-path. 8 images in source (pick best 4). Authentic small-town architecture.

posts.text:
Ent≈ç, Oki Islands, 50km off Shimane. ÈÅ†Â≥∂ means 'exile island' ‚Äî where Japan sent emperors it wanted to forget. Mount Fuji Architects Studio built the hotel into the cliff. Cross-laminated timber. Rooms are mostly window.

üì∑ @sora413s
posts.notes: Modern architecture on remote island. Verify: Mount Fuji Architects Studio, opened 2021. 3K likes.

posts.text:
Kikuya (ËèäÂ±ã), Shuzenji, Shizuoka. 400 years old. In 1910, Natsume S≈çseki checked in to recover from a stomach ulcer and nearly died here ‚Äî the ‰øÆÂñÑÂØ∫„ÅÆÂ§ßÊÇ£ (Shuzenji no Taikan). He wrote about it after. The inn still has his room.
üì∑ @mm__ii89
posts.notes: VERIFIED: Kikuya (ÊπØÂõûÂªä ËèäÂ±ã) in Shuzenji. Soseki stayed Aug-Oct 1910, nearly died. 6.3K likes. 3rd mm__ii89 post - space from others.

posts.text:
Kyoto. Temples, wooden gates, stone paths. Hard to photograph without accidentally catching a UNESCO site in the background.
üì∑ @VERISUKE0805
posts.notes: Backup. 1.6K likes. More travel photography than architecture-specific. Caption needs work after viewing images.

posts.text:
Hiroshi Nakamura built a library underground. The ceiling follows the contours of the hillside above it ‚Äî grass, trees, pathways on top. From street level the building doesn't exist. Just a slot cut into the slope for the entrance.
üì∑ @kiku5445
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 9/10. 1351 likes. Perfect fit - features Hiroshi Nakamura's underground library architecture with
posts.ig_skip_reason: not found on IG (deleted or failed)

posts.text:
12 tatami mats. 216 square feet, 1LDK, two people. Kitchen counter doubles as the dining table. Bed frame has drawers. In Japan a 40sqm apartment is considered spacious for a couple.
üì∑ @3Dcgrooms
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 7/10. 821 likes. Shows Japanese apartment interior (12Áï≥ 1LDK for 2 people) with good engagement.

posts.text:
Four Kyoto temples, each built around a different way of framing what's outside. Kiyomizu-dera hangs 13 meters over the hillside on 139 pillars, no nails. The others use shakkei ‚Äî borrowed scenery ‚Äî pulling distant mountains into the frame.

üì∑ @_mint1996
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 8/10. 221 likes. High-quality photos of iconic Kyoto temples and traditional architecture across

posts.text:
HOIKIENG19 House by Hinzstudio in Vietnam. The front facade is almost entirely concrete louvers ‚Äî vertical fins angled to let air through while blocking direct sun from the street. Behind that screen, the house opens up with full-height glazing and a courtyard that pulls light down through all three floors. The louvers do the privacy work, so the interior walls don't have to.

üì∑ @illustrarch
posts.notes: Dropped ‚Äî Vietnamese architecture, not Japanese. Score 6/10.

posts.text:
A ryokan in Izu built around solo travelers. Six room types, 100% natural hot spring source, and the outdoor rotenburo can be reserved privately at no extra charge. Meals are served in a private dining room using local ingredients ‚Äî no shared tables, no awkward communal breakfasts. Every part of the stay is designed so you never have to perform sociability.

üì∑ @mm__ii89
posts.notes: Dropped ‚Äî thinning mm__ii89 posts (5 was too many from one account).

posts.text:
Kissaten Julian in Fujisawa. A junkissa ‚Äî pure coffee, no alcohol. Named after the protagonist of Stendhal's Le Rouge et le Noir. Porthole windows. If you've read 20th Century Boys, this is the kind of place Urasawa based Caf√© San Francisco on.

üì∑ @creambeefsoda
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 8/10. 1494 likes.

posts.text:
A ryokan in Izu that doesn't accept guests under 12. Thin walls, fusuma, and engawa work better when nobody's running through them. Most places in Izu went family-friendly in the 2010s. This one went the other way.

üì∑ @mm__ii89
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 6/10. 2802 likes. Adult-only ryokan in Izu.

posts.text:
Togamiya Ryokan in Kitaibaraki, Ibaraki Prefecture. A fishing port town on the Pacific coast, about 30 minutes from the Fukushima border. The room opens straight onto the harbor ‚Äî you watch the boats come in from the tatami.

üì∑ @mido25risen
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 7/10. 847 likes. Ryokan on Pacific coast, Ibaraki.

posts.text:
The former Yanashita Residence in Negishi, Yokohama. Taisho era. The bathroom has a goemonburo ‚Äî cast-iron tub heated from below by fire. The ceiling is oriage g≈çtenj≈ç, a coffered design normally reserved for formal reception halls. They put it over the bathtub.

üì∑ @AMFFCRAFTWORK
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 9/10. 364 likes. Historic Yokohama residence bathroom.

posts.text:
Former Honda Tadatsugu residence, built 1932 in Tokyo's Setagaya ward. Spanish-style. Disassembled and moved to Okazaki, Aichi piece by piece in 2012. The bathroom still has the original decorative tile and stained glass. A private family home, not a hotel.

üì∑ @AMFFCRAFTWORK
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 9/10. 792 likes. 1932 Spanish-style home relocated to Aichi.

posts.text:
Opened May 2025 in Shizuoka. The room is basically built around the view ‚Äî floor-to-ceiling glass on two sides, ceiling height kept low to frame the mountains instead of the sky. The tub sits at the window line so the water surface meets the horizon. No curtains in sight.

üì∑ @mm__ii89
posts.notes: Dropped ‚Äî thinning mm__ii89 posts (5 was too many from one account).

posts.text:
Vogue Japan's list of aspirational ryokan ‚Äî the ones Japanese travelers save up for. The photography tells you what these places prioritize: the bath, the garden view, the kaiseki spread. Not the lobby.

üì∑ @voguejp
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 7/10. 762 likes. Vogue Japan ryokan roundup. Moved to Feb 11 AM.

posts.text:
Kyoto under snow. The city gets meaningful snowfall maybe five or six times a winter, and it rarely sticks past midmorning. Locals check the forecast and set alarms ‚Äî if you want to see the temples white, you have a two-hour window before it melts.

üì∑ @urapon_pic
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 8/10. 75 likes. Beautiful snow-covered Kyoto imagery aligns perfectly with Japanese aesthetic co

posts.text:
60-year-old Japanese house restored with a circular engawa wrapping the entire exterior. The canopy follows the same curve. One continuous loop of outdoor-indoor space you can walk without turning a corner.

üì∑ @designboom
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 9/10. 37 likes. Moved from Feb 7 (too many posts that day).

posts.text:
Sauna inside a historic building. Japan has dozens of these now ‚Äî old structures that couldn't survive as museums getting converted into sauna facilities. Users pay per visit, come back weekly, need little space. Preservation funded by sweat.

üì∑ @kiwamisauna2
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 8/10. 643 likes. Historic building turned sauna. Moved to Feb 12 AM.

posts.text:
Whole-house machiya rental in Kanazawa's samurai district. 70+ sqm, full kitchen. Nagamachi bukeyashiki area ‚Äî Edo-period samurai residences. Guests buy seafood at ≈åmich≈ç Market and cook it here. Split between a group, cheaper than a hotel.

üì∑ @cobb_room
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 9/10. 363 likes. Machiya rental in Kanazawa samurai district.

posts.text:
Koji Ide, "the magician of slopes." His firm SUM Design specialized in hillside lots other architects wouldn't touch. This one in Asao-ku, Kawasaki ‚Äî 117.55 sqm on a grade steep enough to scare off most developers. Ide died years ago. The houses still sell.

üì∑ @tokyo__r
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 9/10. 1079 likes. Koji Ide slope housing in Kawasaki.

posts.text:
A preserved estate with both Japanese and Western wings. Shoji hallway in one room, marble fireplace and coffered ceiling in the next. Meiji-era wealthy families built like this. One half for guests, one half for living.

üì∑ @nori7770
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 8/10. 3287 likes. Caption written based on images ‚Äî estate with both Japanese and Western rooms.

posts.text:
Nishimuraya Honkan in Kinosaki Onsen. Open since 1860. The rooms don't try to impress you ‚Äî wood, tatami, shoji, garden view. No welcome speech, no guided tour of the room. Staff read distance perfectly. You sit down and two hours vanish.

üì∑ @fire55miya
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 8/10. 790 likes. High-quality content about traditional Japanese hospitality and interior design

posts.text:
Office in Hashima by PERMANENT + Atelier Nagara. The roof rolls and dips to match the flat agricultural terrain around it ‚Äî one continuous form over the whole building. No parapets, no hard edges. Just corrugated steel following the curve.

Photo: Kenta Hasegawa
üì∑ @tecture1
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 9/10. 120 likes. Perfect fit - high-quality Japanese architecture content with professional photo

posts.text:
Hoshinoya Kyoto has no road access. You check in by boarding a boat on the Oi River. The 15-minute ride upstream is the only way to reach the property.

üì∑ @fire55miya
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 9/10. 79 likes. High-quality content about Hoshinoya Kyoto, a premier Japanese luxury resort kno

posts.text:
Yayoi House by Takeshi Hosaka Architects in Tokyo. The entire roof is a curved concrete shell, just 200mm thick, that collects rainwater and funnels it into a garden below. The house has no gutters. The roof is the gutter.

üì∑ @kotecinho
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 9/10. 562 likes. Perfect content match - Japanese residential architecture by renowned architect

posts.text:
Oku-Yugawara Yui. A ryokan tucked into the deepest part of the Yugawara valley ‚Äî past the other onsen, past the last convenience store. Only 8 rooms. Every one faces the river. No day-use visitors allowed. Guests only.

üì∑ @fire55miya

posts.text:
Gora Kadan in Hakone sits on the former summer villa grounds of the Imperial Shimazu family. The ryokan kept the original stone walls and garden layout from the 1930s estate. Room count: 44. Guest-to-staff ratio: nearly 1:1.

üì∑ @fire55miya
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 8/10. 2141 likes. High-quality post about Gora Kadan, a prestigious traditional Japanese inn in Ha

posts.text:
A vacation house in Karuizawa by Mutsue Hayakusa / Cellspace. The roof curves to follow the trunks and branches of the surrounding trees. Inside, one open room under a wooden ceiling that catches green light reflected off the moss garden below.

üì∑ @JapanArchitects
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 9/10. 86 likes. Perfect content - Japanese residential architecture with moss garden, curved roo

posts.text:
St. Mary's Cathedral, Tokyo. Kenzo Tange, 1964. Eight hyperbolic parabolic shells clad in stainless steel, shaped so the roof forms a cross visible only from above. The interior has no columns ‚Äî the walls themselves carry the load.

üì∑ @luusssso
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 8/10. 3063 likes. High-quality architectural content featuring iconic Japanese Brutalist design by

posts.text:
Yasuyo Building, Tokyo. Architect Nobumichi Akashi, 1969. Each floor rotates 22.5 degrees from the one below it. Eight floors, 180-degree total rotation from ground to roof.

üì∑ @4AAAAart
posts.notes: From bookmarks. Score 9/10. 2774 likes. Perfect fit - iconic Japanese architecture with strong visual appeal and high en

posts.text:
This ryokan in Atami has private onsen baths available 24 hours. You can soak at sunrise watching the ocean. No reservations, no time limits ‚Äî just walk in whenever you want.

üì∑ @mm__ii89
posts.notes: From bookmarks. 897 likes. Japanese ryokan/onsen with scenic views and architectural elements. Atami hot sp

posts.text:
A kominka within walking distance of Nagoya Station, bought specifically because the minpaku market got too crowded for cookie-cutter listings. Being converted into a small hotel. The owner's brief: a hideaway that feels isolated from the city noise around it.

üì∑ @rai703rai
posts.notes: From bookmarks. 117 likes. Japanese kominka (old traditional house) renovation project in Nagoya - converti

posts.text:
Ninnaji's omuro-zakura bloom later than almost every other cherry tree in Kyoto. They grow to about 2 meters ‚Äî short enough that the flowers hit you at eye level. The temple's been timing its public openings around that late bloom for decades.

üì∑ @_mint1996
posts.notes: From bookmarks. 238 likes. High-quality post featuring iconic Kyoto temples and gardens with seasonal focus

posts.text:
Kinkaku-ji's top two floors are covered in gold leaf. When snow lands on it, the gold doesn't reflect ‚Äî it glows. The original burned down in 1950. A monk set it on fire. The current one is a 1955 rebuild.

üì∑ @angelicaio81153
posts.notes: From bookmarks. 48 likes. Kinkaku-ji Temple photography with focus on Japanese aesthetic and landscape des

posts.text:
Murin-an in snow. Yamagata Aritomo ‚Äî twice Prime Minister ‚Äî built this garden with 7th-generation landscaper Ogawa Jihei in the 1890s. Kyoto only gets a few real snow days a year. When it hits, the moss garden goes white before noon and green again by evening.

üì∑ @oniwastagram
posts.notes: From bookmarks. 43 likes. Perfect match - Japanese garden design masterpiece by renowned landscape archite
